A heart-wrenching portrait of one of the saddest, most heroic chapters in American history.

[Tartakovsky's] wit and attention to detail enliven a collection of well-known ghosts and ghouls.

Director David Guy Levy's witless homage to the "Saw" franchise and its ilk.
When it comes to "Girls Against Boys," it's a draw - everyone loses.
Meanders aimlessly around too-familiar territory.
[It] just seems to want to gin up a lot of high-fiving for a lot of shooting, and right now is the least palatable time I can think of for that.

movie_review_blurb: [An] ethereal slice of life in the San Fernando Valley ...
Tonally, the film swings between whispery romance and ominous horror as it explores the dark side of love and lust ...
The mellow Laue, clearly still mourning the death of his dad, makes a likable enough subject, if sometimes low-key to the point of dull.
movie_title: Long Shot The Kevin Laue Story (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This is a compelling and comprehensive guide to one of the most Kafkaesque crime stories in American history.

Why, Salma Hayek? Why?

Olsen nails it as Taylor, who speaks almost exclusively in superlatives: "Ohmygod, you're my favorite person I've ever met!"
It's not to be missed.

movie_review_blurb: Here is a neat, little slow burn of a comedy that upends the cheating-spouse narrative; even its title is cheekily misleading.

Our gradual, voluntary loss of privacy is ripe for dramatization, but this movie arrives when people are actually backing up from social media.
For a bad movie, this one is an awful lot of fun.

"The Fate of the Furious" begins and ends with adrenaline-spiking scenes - a drag race through Havana, an airplane brawl - that remind you why this gear-head franchise is still purring along. As for the two hours in between . . . not so much.
There are countless moments during which Hawn and Schumer simply stare at each other, seemingly as baffled as I was by the dullness of it all.
It's been a week since I saw "Baby Driver," and I'm still pleasantly buzzed.
A smart and tender movie that was swept a bit under the rug by its misguided designation as "the abortion comedy."
Despite being set in the late 1970s, "20th Century Women" feels like the perfect movie for this moment.

Melissa McCarthy, Kristin Wiig, Kate McKinnon and Leslie Jones make a formidable comic team in their own right - though McKinnon steals the show as oddball physics geek Holtzmann (the Egon, if you will).

On the whole, it's a pitch-perfect love letter to "Ab Fab" devotees. As for newcomers? My advice: See it after a couple of Stolis, darling, and you'll be just fine.
Feels both deeply rote and way overpacked with characters.

Directors Greg Tiernan and Conrad Vernon are working with a first-rate cast, running wild with stereotypes and daring you to be offended.

Despite a traditional-seeming quest for a suit of armor and a sword, the film's intrinsic message is all about the transformative powers of music and love. It's a movie the whole family can rock out to.

[A] soggy mess of a movie ...
The film's endless scenes of debauchery and exploitation don't really yield much of a take-away ...
Like its wastoid heroine, "Antibirth" is a mess - but an interesting one.

A wild trip with a highly unreliable narrator.
Enough laughs here to merit this gaffe-filled outing with Ms. Jones.

Jarmusch salutes a life with a refreshing lack of drama.

movie_review_blurb: With a mischievous, metaphysical flourish, "Doctor Strange" administers some much-needed CPR to the flagging superhero genre.

I cracked up here and there watching this broad heist comedy, but it wasn't laughter I felt great about.

Chilling, subversive ...

A pointless flail of expensive (yet, somehow, cheap-looking) CGI that no amount of tacked-on quips, or even Gadot's luminescent star power, can rescue.

Alexander Payne's new sci-fi comedy, about a near future in which humans can opt to "go small," squanders its big ideas in record time.
"The Post" may be all-too-easy Oscar bait, but it's as satisfying and polished as you'd expect.
Bening forgoes vanity and digs into the humiliation Grahame felt as she aged out of the vampy roles Hollywood typecast her in. Bell brings a sturdy humanity to Peter ...

movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

The definitive portrait of a man still frequently cited as the world's greatest actor.

movie_review_blurb: A dark and ultimately quite nasty psychological thriller from actor/writer/debut director Joel Edgerton, who manages to yank the carpet out from under his audience a couple of times.
"Mistress America" never falters in its case study of a complicated female friendship.

Per Swanberg's signature style, the dialogue is largely improvised, the performances loose and funny. This may be his most star-studded cast yet, but the work is as intimate ("mumblecore" is so passé) as ever.

For a story whose appeal hinges on the saving grace of getting a "purpose-driven life," this one's got remarkably little of it.
Grim but worthwhile, this documentary on the war against polio in Pakistan often recalls our own anti-vaxer movement, with needlessly sickened children the depressing commonality.
Elegantly touching ...
Karas doesn't exactly reinvent the wheel as he puts this odd couple through the paces of getting in shape and reconciling old wounds, but he's helped by some laugh-out-loud quirk ...
Struggles to stay afloat on the considerable charm of its stars - Evans and Alice Eve - but is sunk by too much schmaltz (even for the Lower East Side).
Joining the indie monster-girl genre alongside "Ginger Snaps," "Teeth" and "Let the Right One In" is this melancholy Danish werewolf tale from debut director Jonas Alexander Arnby.

Car racing, vengeance, logic-defying stunts and stuff blowing up. Too much stuff blowing up, really. We came for the cars and their reckless, gorgeous drivers; we can get explosions anywhere.

A plodding, incoherent mess starring Skarsgard and his abs, which look more real than any of his CGI jungle companions.

This tried and tested format would be heavy going if it weren't for the raunchy nature of the reminiscences, the measured tones of Mapplethorpe's voice explaining his work and the confrontational beauty of the photographs interspersed with the interviews.
The film cannot hope to be all-encompassing, but it conveys the essence of Berger's ideas in an extremely engaging and intelligent way.
movie_title: The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I'm clobbered into silent despair by the numbers and the overwhelming scale of the challenge they represent.
Stanley Tucci's Final Portrait, his first film in 10 years, is in a class of its own.
movie_title: It's So Easy and Other Lies (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Stanley Tucci's Final Portrait, his first film in 10 years, is in a class of its own.
A bleak, annoyingly quirky Gen-X recasting of the When Harry Met Sally notion that true love is based on friendship.
The whole film is permeated with tenderness for its hurt characters, whom Minghella sees as just a small slice in the fellowship of people who love and suffer.
When Contact finally comes alive, it leaves you frightened and thrilled and emotionally overwrought, as only a child can be. The rest is pandering.
You could do far worse than the quest for a reasonable adult happiness.
Jean-Marc Vallée just deconstructed his oeuvre, his influences, and the A-list Hollywood prestige picture so that he could put it back together again as something even better.
The mix of drama and humor works well here and comedic backgrounds of many of Trumbo's stars becomes an incredible asset, adding almost perfect timing to many a line-reading.
High-Rise's wild descent into dog-eating degradation is an imperfect ride, with Wheatley gleefully bringing almost as much anarchy to his direction as his characters bring to their residence.
Where To Invade Next shows almost no hints of what was ailing Moore six years ago. It's a refreshing return to form both in terms of ethos and artistic merit.

With Anomalisa, Kaufman makes the case for a kinder and gentler treatment, and he might be on to something. The unflinching realization that we are all alone in this indifferent world has never hurt quite so good.
James White is an unflinching portrait of the would-be artist as a flailing and spoiled 20-something, gripping from its sensory overload of a first scene all the way to its emotional final act.
I Saw the Light is essentially two hours of Hank Williams wandering around, singing, and being cantankerous while almost all of the major moments in his life happen slightly off screen.

The Danish Girl isn't brave. It's the blue chip stock of the film world, a safe investment that has predictable returns, and cheats both its subject matter and artistry of any truly meaningful gains in the process.
Kill Your Friends is effective and enjoyable in the way that dusty music compilations are.
Love is a lot like a questionable one night stand with a moderately talented lover. As long as you can enjoy it for what it is, you can get a decent thrill out of the experience...
Green Room proves playfully unpredictable to the very last frame. Perhaps the only thing more exciting than waiting to see what transpires is waiting to see what Saulnier does next.
This clearly isn't a film by or for U.N.C.L.E. nerds and while that's frustrating from the perspective of an overly possessive fan, it's understandable when you remove that bias.

It's an imperfect union, but Posthumous still manages to charm more often than it disappoints. And it firmly establishes Lulu Wang as an artist who won't have to wait until after her death to be appreciated in her field.
Watching all 62 films consecutively provides an experience every bit as exciting, thought-provoking, and ultimately ephemeral as an LED-laden train full of artists passing in the night.
Diamond Tongues is a brilliant and realistic portrait of the young artist as a bitter borderline failure.
Heaven Adores You works best if you approach it like a mixtape or a fanzine. Watching the film feels just like discovering him on DIY mixtapes so many years ago.
The Dead Lands occasionally runs the risk of becoming too preachy or cheesy - most unironic martial arts films do - but it's still a thoughtful and exhilarating introduction to its subject matter
Kung Fu Elliot allows viewers to become attached enough to Elliot that his lying and cheating behavior almost feels like a personal betrayal when you watch it.

Hardcore delivers creative action sequence after action sequence, and it's almost as fun to think about how they managed to choreograph and shoot the battles and chase scenes as it is to suspend your disbelief and go along for the ride.
Laurie Anderson has put her heart and soul into this film. And any viewer who is willing to invest their time and emotions in it will be richly, if heartbreakingly, rewarded.

The Witch is worth watching. Just don't get too wrapped up in the hysteria that surrounds it. As the film itself so admirably demonstrates, unquestioned passion and devotion doesn't tend to end particularly well.

Charlotte Rampling is nothing short of a revelation in 45 Years, delivering a tour de force so strong, so skilled and measured, and yet so emotionally fraught that it threatens to eclipse both her own career, and the rest of the film.
Filmed in aquatic hues and bathed in nostalgic mid-century style, The Shape of Water is both a love story and a love letter to monster movies, musicals, and classic cinema.
By the time that Glen is flippantly apologizing to "all women," it's clear that neither he nor his creator intend to take their world anywhere new, let alone shocking.
On every level, Long Time Running offers something new to the rock doc genre and to Tragically Hip enthusiasts.
Professor Marston is as traditional in structure as it is divergent in content. And, arguably, that is in itself subversive.
In Lady Bird, Gerwig cares about her characters enough to treat them with respect when they deserve it and to kindly skewer them when they deserve that.
Haigh has established himself as an artist eminently capable of making incredibly human films about incredibly human pain.
Molly's Game is a successful crime drama, but it's also a film that acknowledges the presence of both good and bad luck in the pursuit of excellence.
Payne's heart might have been in the right place with this one, but the execution feels flippant at best.
Suburbicon's intermittent strengths aren't enough to carry it, let alone make up for its ham-fisted attempts at saying something of greater importance.
On almost every level, in almost every way, Jane is an exemplary work of documentation, storytelling, and filmmaking.
A Haneke who's treading water is still a bizarrely entertaining filmmaker, but the fun is tinged with a hint of disappointment and a certain feeling of lost opportunity.
Free Fire might be a trifle of a quippy, feature-length shootout, but it's the best damned trifle of a quippy, feature-length shootout you'll ever see.

Is this an ecological thriller? A searing look at mankind's destruction of our natural environment? A meditation on how ultimately powerless we are in the face of that same embattled nature? A comedy? An exercise in self-amusement? All of the above?

La La Land is gorgeous, often delightful, and quite satisfying. Its very existence is a triumph, given that an unabashed throwback A-list musical could not have been an easy sell, even for someone coming off of such significant hype.
A United Kingdom hits all of the necessary emotional notes and political intrigue of a solid historical figure drama.

Once the giddy critical pile-on and hate-watching settles down, the (justified) moral outrage that (re)Assignment tries to thwart will end up being the regrettable and forgettable film's only lasting legacy.

Be patient. Arrival falls just short of perfect thanks to an expositional hiccup midway through the film and a climax that hinges on a borderline-hokey revelation, but the end will more than justify these ever so slightly sloppy means.
Mascots might be a lesser addition to the Guest oeuvre, but it's a welcome one nonetheless.

None of the thoughtfulness, care, or compassion that was so evident in Ford's 2009 directorial debut A Single Man is evident in this follow-up feature. Much like Susan herself, it's all very well-funded, well put-together, and agonizingly empty.
Given that The Salesman strives to be far more than a revenge thriller, Emad's story isn't enough to make it an unqualified triumph, but it's still a genuinely good film, and worth watching.
You're likely to be so invested in both the story and its rules that you can't help but follow Lanthimos and his crew through to their grisly, well-executed conclusion.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of simple heroes or avatars for big ideas about equality, Loving delivers complex, imperfect human beings who are struggling to find their place in a far from perfect world.
We see-almost from the inside-the evolution of Cobain's sensitive brilliance and the art and destruction that it fed.

Watching the Fox version is a strange experience, because you feel that Ortega both understands this and betrays it, or that [HSM] and its ilk are such a part of his DNA that he doesn't know the difference between good and bad anymore.
movie_title: The Rocky Horror Picture Show: Let's Do the Time Warp Again (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The backdrop of a New York of yesteryear is nice, but it's easy to mistake being outdated for nostalgic.
Bado is a compelling and at times magnetic presence, and the film misses her whenever she's offscreen.
Her is told from Theo's perspective, and all he can ever really know about Samantha is that she's infinite-and when it comes to another person, what's more real than that?

The first act seems to promise 70 more minutes of rambling episodes, at the overbearing whim of a director toying with an insufferable protagonist. It's a bit of a shock, then, when Crystal Fairy turns out to be really good.
[Wan] combines the ambiance of horror's leisure-suit heyday with the more recent brand of well-timed what's-that-in-the-mirror scares.
The film never musters the humor nor the sex appeal to carry off its study of ultra-Freudian arrested development.
There's the backbone of a better film here, it just needs some ornaments.

Slow West is not badly paced-not at all-but it does present a challenge to the viewer. It's not slow so much as wandering, and you have to be willing to roll with deeply weird moments interspersed with violence and tragedy.

For the six of you who like Now You See Me, #2 offers more of the same so you ought to like the sequel. For everyone else, it's barely passable but it will do in a pinch, if you really need to check out for a couple hours.
Free State of Jones is too boring to be bad in an interesting way and too infuriating to be bad in a fun way. It can best be summed up in four words: Whitesplaining the Civil War.
There are no stakes and every problem encountered is resolved through a convenient device. They might as well have called it MacGuffin: The Movie.
My ribs actually hurt by the end of Sausage Party. That's the highest praise I can give it-Sausage Party is a rib-sprainer.
The Jungle Book is charming from start to finish. Neel Sethi is adorable as Mowgli, and the stunning visuals are completely convincing.
The Night Before is destined to become annual holiday viewing for a lot of people-including me-and is also one of the funniest movies of the year.
Math-Man Begins includes an ACCOUNTING MONTAGE and gets progressively stupider as it goes along, which means by the end you're pressed to hold back howling laughter.
The movie is a little messy, as it meanders along with Davis's fits and starts, but if you're willing to just roll with it, the reward is a very satisfying emotional arc.
Film is a storytelling medium, and while a story doesn't necessarily have to have a three act structure, it does need a beginning, a middle, and an end. I Smile Back is all middle.
I have a feeling this movie only exists because of people doing [Johnny] Depp favors.
What a wasted opportunity.

Ant-Man is a very enjoyable movie on its own merit. Paul Rudd's everyman charm is put to good use as Scott Lang, but Michael Pena walks away with the best parts of the movie as Scott's former cell mate, Luis.
After 70 minutes of being a grimdark body horror take on superheroes, Fantastic Four turns into an Avengers movie. You can actually hear the Fox execs shouting, "Be more like the Avengers!"
This script is so fundamentally flawed I can't imagine anyone wanting to produce it.
Joel Edgerton just released his directorial debut, The Gift, and it's really good. So while yes, fewer actors should become directors, Joel Edgerton gets a pass because he is actually good at it.
This is [Charlotte] Rampling's film from beginning to end, and she holds the screen effortlessly.
It's basically just Annie Hall set in the 1930s, but he's remade Annie Hall like nineteen times and no one has cared yet, so I don't see why anyone will care now.
I'll say this for The Longest Ride: It did not make me want to burn anything down.
Creed is flawless-they ought to teach it in film school.
It's too bad-in the right, Herzogian hands, this could have been one of the great Man vs. Nature epics in cinema. Instead it's a boring, lame Moby Dick spin-off.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The pay-off pairing is Scotty (Simon Pegg) and Jaylah, both engineers-the way Scotty instantly recognizes and respects Jaylah's mechanical gift is incredibly refreshing.
There's nothing memorable about Minions, a problem compounded by [Sandra] Bullock's completely forgettable efforts as Scarlett.
But it is a good movie, timing aside, and if the sequel had doubled-down on the quirky casting and morally conflicted plot, the Reacher franchise could be onto something.
Where Insurgent is like a horrible episode of Quantum Leap, Allegiant is terrible rip-off of The Truman Show.
With a better director, The Boss could maybe be a B-, but [Ben] Falcone's flat, inert direction dooms it to C status.
While Unfinished Business is not good and I do not recommend it, it also didn't make me want to pour bleach in my eyes.
There is only one possible conclusion: The Transpoter Refueled was made by crazy people.
Inferno isn't good, but it's not as bad as Decaf Indiana Jones has been, and it's almost bearable just for Irrfan Khan.

But the MVP is John C. Reilly as Marlow, who was stranded on Skull Island after crash-landing there in World War II. Reilly 100% understands the movie he's in and every bit of Kong that works that doesn't involve monsters works because of Reilly.
Arrival is the Platonic Ideal of mainstream filmmaking-a smart film that doesn't talk down to its audience and works as not only a science fiction film but also a thriller.
For a movie about the breaking point of the British Suffragette movement that saw marches and demonstrations turn to vandalism and arson, Suffragette is hella boring.
[Charlize] Theron is SPECTACULAR as Lorraine, leading with Lorraine's spy-trained shrewdness and emotional armor, but also touching on moments of vulnerability that she can't afford to expose.
Despite its pretensions, The 9th Life of Louis Drax is not hard to figure out, and no amount of beautifully lit dream imagery makes up for a recycled whodunit.
Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales is complete garbage.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Shot for approximately seven dollars, The Dark Tower is a muddy, unattractive picture with terribly choreographed and filmed action.
That's the nicest thing I can say about Wish Upon: It reminds me of one of the most unintentionally hilarious scenes ever filmed.

Ingrid Goes West is equal parts scathing social satire, horror movie, and character portrait. It's self-aware enough to include a Single White Female joke, but it's not the kind of jokey movie that winks at itself.
The Trip to Spain is more of the same, but that's not so bad when "the same" is the film equivalent of a Michelin-starred meal.
Beasts as a film is worthy of its terrific lead performances. In case there was any doubt, Fukunaga is a MAJOR talent, and ought to be writing his own ticket from here on out.
The Bronze is an unfunny, overlong parade of squandered potential. It's extremely frustrating.
I don't hate it, but I'm not sure I really like it, either.. Certain Women is pretty much just for hardcore cinephiles who get off on shot composition and editing, and for giving us Lily Gladstone.
While Detroit is very good at making you feel things, it's less good at telling a complete story. The film almost feels unfinished.
It's impossible not to be moved by SOMETHING in Zookeeper, and Caro effectively recreates the Warsaw Ghetto and its myriad horrors without sinking to exploitation or crass violence.
Please don't bother with Taken 3. There's nothing redeemable about it.
I don't know how else to put it -- it's bad. It's a mess. It's barely functional as a piece of entertainment and not at all as a movie.
The real crime in Money Monster is wasting all this talent on such a mediocre movie.

The Forest made me wonder if the reason we have yet to see the Matthew McConaughey/Ken Watanabe film Sea of Trees, also about Aokigahara, is because it's really hard to make a movie about the suicide forest that isn't tasteless and exploitative.

The final product is that The Force Awakens is emotionally satisfying, but you kind of have to play dumb to get along with it. It's a good movie-a really good one, on the surface level-but it falls just short of great.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The problem with The Intern is that it's always about the changes Jules can make to better fit into traditional ideals of womanhood, and not how Jules can redefine those roles and definitions to make the world work for her.
This is just a feature-length anti-bullying PSA, and dear lord is it tedious.
There's a detached sense of boredom in Mascots, as if [Christopher] Guest himself is tired of his schtick.
Daddy's Home is not entertaining. It's a lazily executed painful waste of talented performers.

The Martian is not self-serious, and is a reminder that you can make a movie with real stakes, depth, and tension and still include humor-it does not have to be one or the other (I'm looking at you, Christopher Nolan).

Bridge of Spies is a crisp, slow-burning thriller that holds a lot of winks. It's suspenseful, sure, but so confident in the way it forges a delicate balance between international intrigue and brevity.

A movie like this really needs a more charming lead that can play the badness for laughs, like Bruce Campbell, but instead we're stuck watching Vin Diesel take his weekend LARP tournament very, very seriously.
[Helen] Mirren is flawless, in turns feisty and dignified, and she elevates mediocre, paint-by-numbers biopic material into something moderately engaging.

Mechanic: Resurrection starts off promising, with the double-blackmailing and boat explosions, but then it tries to be a B-grade Mission: Impossible and ends up flat and dull. What a waste of The Stath.

Even by B-movie, January horror movie, expecting-the-worst standards, Cressida Bonas is a Bad Actress. But at least she's not alone in The Bye Bye Man, where everyone is a bad actor except Faye Dunaway because she's Faye Dunaway.

Fences comes to the stage almost entirely intact, including Wilson's beautiful language and scenery-chewing monologues, and as Troy [Denzel] Washington does some of his finest acting work in recent memory.

Nicholas Hoult and Kristen Stewart are INSANELY BEAUTIFUL. You could watch this on mute and just be struck by the visuals, even if Doremus's hand-held camerawork doesn't make a ton of sense-at least he shows his stars off to advantage.
For a film about finessing texts, there isn't much finesse in Genius.
Nina feels like a movie made by people who fundamentally misunderstood Nina Simone. It conclusively proves that representation behind the camera is as important as representation on screen.
Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials takes about three minutes to figure out and then another one hundred and twenty-seven minutes to end.

Zoolander 2 isn't secretly brilliant like its predecessor, nor does it have the kind of absurd humor it takes time to unpack. It's just a bad movie, embodying every reason that comedy sequels are a bad idea 99% of the time.
Monster Trucks is exactly the kind of movie that should cost studio brass their jobs.
Good luck picking a favorite fight, because every action scene is incredible.
It would be so easy to lambast Pixels as a cravenly lazy, creatively defunct, possible Ponzi scheme in which audience dollars are siphoned into Adam Sandler's private jet fund.
Other People is a solid middle-of-the-pack indie cancer dramedy.
This movie is made up of the most infuriating conveniences.
If you're open to the strange nature of the film and its duality, then you're in for a good time with a truly unique film.
The movie, directed by yet another Key & Peele alum, Peter Atencio, is at its best during action scenes, or any time the camera cuts to Keanu...
What Friends needs is a leading man who can propel us past the inherent boredom of this artistic endeavor by virtue of his charisma, but Zac Efron is not that guy...
... if you're into a decently scary movie that mines fright from well-executed, if familiar, jump scares and atmospherics, then Lights Out is the movie for you.
This movie is a complete waste of time and no one should see it.
... Too many characters, too great a time span, and lack of focus on the main event.
It's mostly just boring, and then toward the end it's actually confounding.
If you really want an unpretentious, sweet romantic movie, you deserve a whole hell of a lot better than Big Stone Gap.
... Sing Street is sweet and fun and well worth a watch.
The LEGO Batman Movie gets you laughing right from the start...
The plot is generic and hardly matters.
The Infiltrator is entertaining enough, and makes for solid summer counter-programming.
... our typical loud, dumb, overlong Michael Bay celebration of guns, guys, and America.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There is a lot to admire about Barthes' production values, but little to actually enjoy in the storytelling.
It's a reasonably effective thriller that works because of its A+ cast and one really well executed action set piece in the middle of the movie.
Fans of Tom Hardy will find plenty to like, but no one else has a reason to watch this movie.
This is a really bad non-movie, alienating to pre-existing fans and mystifying to everyone else.
It's a fantastic movie from top to bottom, and an utter delight to watch.
... another sub-par Christmas "comedy" in which actors play characters that are more like guesses about what real people are like than representations of actual human people.
It's not weird-that's actually part of the problem-it's just bad.
Goosebumps is not a faithful adaptation of the books, but it is a fun introduction to horror for kids.
... a charming introduction to young new fans.
... Fist Fight is a pass.
The Boy, on the other hand, is a dumb garbage movie that I recommend to no one.
The Visit is more like a conventional card trick than a full-scale illusion, but it has some decent scare moments...
Dark Places aims for the same kind of shocking twists and reveals as Gone Girl, but falls woefully short.
Bleed hits every well-trod beat and expectation of the genre, and is such a rote exercise it might as well be called Boxing: The Movie, or Sports Comeback: The True Hollywood Story.
We've seen enough Liam Neeson Revenge Man movies to know how they work and this one is particularly interchangeable with any of the others.
... The Age of Adaline is incredibly boring.
This is Braff's first mainstream film effort, and he falls back on his sitcom roots, going broad with the humor and pretty pedestrian in style.
There is a lot to dazzle in High-Rise, and some very good performances to enjoy, but there's also a bit of an "emperor without clothes" feeling.
Don't get me wrong-it's bad. It's just that you probably think it's a blazing inferno chemical disaster fire, and it's not. It's more like a mildly alarming dumpster fire.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The action is atrocious, and after the brass-balled sequences of Rogue Nation, Spectre feels especially flat.
Vacation is not an offensively bad movie. It's not very funny, but at least it's not openly contemptuous of its audience.
Featuring really nice comedic performances from Bonneville, Hawkins, and Kidman, Paddington is a pleasant surprise.
It's really only for the Ab Fab loyal, but if you're a sweetie darling, Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie is a satisfying trip back into Patsy and Edina's self-obsessed world.
Carol is a strange film to parse. It's certainly one of the very best made and well-acted films of the year, but its sum total is cold and reserved.
It is baffling how bad The Darkness is.
This is a new Disney classic.

The setup of The House is so bleak that its humor by necessity must be scathing in response. But The House doesn't want to be scathing, it wants Ferrell to do his man-baby thing while Poehler struts around with a butane kitchen torch.
The action in London is equivalent to watching someone else play video games, and there are a handful of first-person POV shots that make it even more game-like. It's also largely incoherent.
Overall Truth is a strong film, examining the side of the story that wasn't really considered at the time and fueled by Blanchett's stellar performance.
The Glass Castle wants to be an old-fashioned weepy but the story borders more on horror.
Unless you're a hardcore horror nerd, Unfriended is not essential viewing. But it is a surprisingly decent film, and the real-life framework for the narrative gives the movie a little extra punch.
I went into Chris Rock's Top Five with a checklist of expectations, and I am happy to say that my expectations were met, and even exceeded in places.
It is, without doubt, one of the best films you'll see this year. (Probably, this decade.) Maybe even the best.
Overall, Lost River isn't worth its rental fee, unless you absolutely must see Gosling's effort for yourself. Otherwise, take my word for it-wait until Ryan Gosling makes another movie.
I have uncontrollable hatred for this movie. I hate it with the fire of a thousand suns. It's the dumbest movie I've seen in recent memory.
My Blind Brother is a moderately sweet movie about terrible people. The awkwardness will make you wince, but it also hits on something true about the lengths we go to in the name of being nice.
Films like A Ghost Story-so odd and outside the typical cinematic experience-don't happen often these days, but when they do they can remind us of the power of the cinematic image.
There's no such elegance in The Water Diviner. Crowe's performance is great but he's basically a bull in a china shop, rampaging gracelessly through the emotionally reductive landscape of his film.
Huntsman feels like a movie that resulted from a three-day bender-it probably sounded like a good idea at one point, but no one can remember exactly why.
Goat paints an ugly portrait of young white manhood stewing in its own idiocy until the inevitable tragic result is reached.
Cups will be outright alienating for most people.

The Shallows is a solid B-movie that doesn't pretend to be anything other than a B-movie. That goes a long way in a summer movie season in which several big budget blockbusters have overreached and failed.
Live By Night is dumb in a self-important Oscar bait kind of way.
St. Vincent is not a must-see by any means, unless you're a die-hard Bill Murray fan who has to see everything he's in.
Birdman is a tremendous film. There's no other way to put it. It's an ASTOUNDING technical accomplishment and a genuinely affecting film that is funny, absurd, moving, and sad.
American Pastoral is boring at best, but it will play well to one audience-white suburban parents.
Assassin's Creed is both completely nonsensical and dead boring. The video game curse remains unbroken.
I Saw the Light is not good, and I don't recommend it.
Basically, the only people to whom The Boss Baby appeals are children young enough to still be entertained by jingling keys.
Kingsman manages to skate over a number of tricky concepts with style and aplomb-right up until it doesn't.

Logan Lucky is a fun heist flick with a satisfyingly smart twist, too, full of great performances and deadpan humor and it will eventually find an audience, even if it's not a box office smash. Movies this fun and well-made always do.
As is, it's just a boring, messy movie about annoying people and their annoying robot friend.
... has a terrible cheat ending that ruins whatever mojo it manages to work up.
Brimstone masquerades as religious allegory, but really it's just good ol' fashioned exploitative revenge porn.

The Circle is the second time Tom Hanks has tried a Dave Eggers adaptation, following last year's A Hologram for the King. Like that movie, The Circle doesn't work, although Hanks's performance is better here-albeit, much smaller.
Table 19 is not a perfect movie, but it is charming and there is real emotional weight to the problems people are having.
Columbus is a small, intimate film playing out on a big canvas, a personal drama set amongst titanic works. It's good actors doing good acting in a film shot by a master of composition.
Paterson is a beautiful film, quiet and quietly devastating in a way that won't leave you alone for a while.
It feels like your typical bloated disaster blockbuster.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Blackcoat's Daughter layers on the dread until it's almost physically challenging to keep watching as shadows grow ever more oppressive and the school ever less welcoming. Something wicked this way comes, indeed.
The Witch is an exceptionally well-made horror movie that relies on character-driven drama to create fear, not cheap gimmicks.
... the sum total is a messy, slightly out of focus portrait of a larger than life man.
Without the romantic subtext, Ben-Hur is left with a rather ugly moral about destroying your enemies at all costs and only forgiving them once you've ruined their lives.
It's just amazing that a movie with so much to look at in it is as boring as Ghost is, but this movie is PHENOMENALLY BORING.
More than anything, Florence Foster Jenkins feels like Baby Boomer version of "everybody gets a participation trophy".
... what you have is a surprisingly heartfelt and very good relationship drama trapped in the premise of a bro comedy.
This movie is really good and deserves to be taken on its own merit, but because Cloverfield is invoked in the title, a lot of people expected a literal sequel.
Spare us any more half-baked "comedies"...
It's weird and won't be for everyone, but Alien: Covenant is fun, strange, gross, kinda boring a little bit, and also SCARY.
There's almost a feel of experimentation to parts of Manglehorn, but as 85% of the movie is just a straightforward character drama, those bits don't really fit.
Written by Diablo Cody and directed by Jonathan Demme, Ricki is a mish-mash of styles and tones that don't really hang together all that well...
... a stellar piece of science fiction.
... a searing portrait of holiday-driven despair, a ruthless and harrowing look at emotional burnout and the soul-crushing playacting demanded by the holiday season.
Southside With You is a lovely notion, a celebratory biography, and a slightly presumptuous memorial all wrapped up in a dreamy romantic date movie.
... a surprisingly sentimental and sweet film about an older woman coming of age post-middle age.
Despite its (few) idiosyncrasies, this is a top-notch movie.
Make no mistake: Eddie Redmayne is profoundly terrible in Jupiter Ascending.
Manchester by the Sea is Kenneth Lonergan's third film, and his strongest result yet.
Miracles from Heaven will satisfy its intended audience and do absolutely nothing for anyone else.
Adult Beginners is so middle of the road it's hard to pick on it. It's proficient enough to avoid scathing criticism, but it's not good enough to inspire passion.
I'm going to make more jokes about The Revenant, because this is basically a live action Road Runner cartoon, and DiCaprio is Wile E. Coyote.
Spectacle alone is no longer enough to satisfy, and without a coherent story to support it, The Great Wall falls flat.
So you just have to take the good with the bad. What works in Doctor Strange works REALLY WELL.
Hot Pursuit is a movie so unutterably terrible it defies explanation...
The Stanford Prison Experiment lives and dies by the quality of the performances, because there is very little else in the film.
... botches the zombie angle so badly it's mystifying.
In every technical aspect, Dunkirk IS a marvel. The cinematography is great, the editing is sharp, Nolan's direction is detailed and precise, the sound is OUTSTANDING.
For just ten dollars, you can roll the dice and enjoy your customized Nicholas Sparks White People Experience. Let's play!
Harvey Weinstein should have marketed Tulip Fever as a farce.
It stares down creepy clowns, but turns away from the ultimate evil.
Molly's Game is Jessica Chastain's movie from start to finish.
Characters have no names in mother!, which is the first sign of exactly how pretentious this movie will be.
The biggest problem with Downsizing isn't that it's bad, it's that it's the wrong movie about the wrong character, and starring the wrong person.
Battle of the Sexes is an entertaining and inspiring story about a dogged woman winning against men who don't take her seriously enough.
No one loves monsters as much as Guillermo Del Toro, and his love seeps into every pore of The Shape of Water.
Class, competition, and the world's dumbest criminals converge in this pitch black comedy.
The Killing of a Sacred Deer is nightmarish emotional surrealism.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Disaster Artist is a love letter to movies and the people who dream big enough to make them, even when they have no clue what they're doing.
The Current War is boring, bad history.
This isn't a movie, it's a two hour Wikipedia entry.
Darkest Hour is a study of age and power, and the achieving and decline of both.
The Death of Stalin is a scathingly funny satire about power-mad nerds and bumbling bureaucrats that could only come from Armando Iannucci.
The Mummy labors under its formula but there is some genuinely fun stuff in it.
Three Billboards has anger, violence, tragedy, forgiveness, and revenge of Hellenic proportions, and all because a woman asks a question of a man.
Victoria and Abdul is bizarrely Imperial.
Mostly enjoyable and only slightly too long.
The best thing about Unforgettable is the inevitable episode of How Did This Get Made that it will inspire.
In focusing strictly on gender politics, Coppola renders her protagonists less interesting, which ultimately makes The Beguiled an exercise in selective seeing.
Free Fire is the happiest a movie has made me since John Wick Chapter 2.
If anything, Andrews' Una is directly confrontational toward men.
Nocturnal Animals is, simply, flawless. There is no part of this film that could be changed or subtracted without damaging the rest of it, and there is nothing that needs to be added.
Like Wonder Woman, Homecoming leans into sincerity and the earnestness of its hero, and also like Wonder Woman, it's a better movie for it.
Stone and Gosling, at the top of their respective games, are delightful to watch together.
Logan is well made, though, with SUPERB acting across the board, including franchise-best performances from Jackman and Stewart.
Moana will be remembered more for its music than anything else, which is saying something because the movie itself is damn good.

Passengers is an incredibly creepy movie in which a woman succumbs to Stockholm Syndrome and falls for her stalker and stays with him even though the stupid ending wants to be ambiguous but it's not, this movie never met the concept of subtlety.
It works more than it doesn't, and the story itself feels fresher than Force Awakens because it isn't a repeat of a previous Star Wars movie.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The neon color palette, the classic rock soundtrack, cuts to Drax and Mantis being funny-all of this works to keep Vol. 2 from feeling heavy or overburdened.
The length of Kingsman: The Golden Circle makes it impossible to sustain momentum, and though parts of it are enjoyable enough, it wears out its welcome before the third act even begins.
True Story is completely missable.
Finding Dory will please everyone. No, it's not as sharp as Pixar is capable of being, but it is still fantastically funny, with just enough of a moral to give it a point.
Please forgive me, and don't go see Nine Lives.
There's nothing wrong with #3, but there's nothing especially delightful for surprising about it, either. And it's definitely not original.

The Hobbit is too long and at times a little hard to look at, but fans of Tolkien and/or the first trilogy are bound to be thrilled with a return trip to Middle Earth. Everyone else can come for the HFR and stay for that Gollum/Bilbo throwdown.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Somehow this one manages to be even worse than the last one despite being almost twenty minutes shorter-it still feels like it's nine hundred years long, though.
Brad Pitt's Netflix movie, War Machine, probably didn't play out as well as anyone hoped.
Everest is not a triumphant story of human courage and sacrifice. It's a reminder-we are powerless in the face of Nature's indifference.
This is not high art cinema, but for ninety minutes Mr. Right is just plain fun.

It's a technically marvelous film with some surpassingly dumb moments. It's a movie that seeks to honor an honorable man, but does so at the expense of other honorable men. Hacksaw Ridgeis a flawed film from a deeply flawed filmmaker.
Collateral Beauty is just bad in the bad way.
Sure, it's fun when The Rock punches a torpedo. But not even that can save F8 of the Furious from itself.
Apocalypse is hot garbage because no one had an idea for it beyond "We gotta crank another one of these out before Marvel reclaims the rights".
Time will tell if it's a masterpiece, but at the very least, Blade Runner 2049 is a worthy successor to a groundbreaking film.
My Little Pony: The Movie is a ceaseless nightmare of forced merriment.
Batman v Superman is not the franchise jump-starter anyone wanted. It's poison in the Justice League well.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I'm not going to sit here and pretend like Independence Day is some great movie-it's not. It's nonsensical trash like all of Roland Emmerich's movies.
If you're not getting the picture, Demon is a graphic film. Refn goes for some deeply upsetting beats and lands everyone one of them, but Demon is also surprisingly funny.
Allied is a by the book, old-fashioned wartime romance flick. It's not bad, but it's not really good, either.
There's not much to say about the plot. Second Best suffers from sequelitis, as so many sequels do, in that it's just more of the same.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Written by Kelly Fremon Craig-also making her feature film directorial debut-Seventeen has brilliant dialogue everyone clearly relishes.
Kidnap has no style and no thrill, and so it falls flat.
Melodramatic weepies aren't inherently bad, but no one acts like a real person in Gifted, so the drama falls flat.
It's tone deaf at best and offensive imperialism at worst. Rock the Kasbah is revolting on every level.
Underworld: Blood Wars is a nonsense movie that barely hangs together and no one seems interested in actually being in it.
Morgan is a derivate, clunky, dead boring exercise in science fiction more notable for nepotism than any creative achievement.
There is no reason to ever see this movie.

The Girl on the Train gets a couple big laughs in places I don't think were meant to be funny, and though Blunt, Ferguson, and Bennett are all doing what they can with the material, the movie is so poorly written there's no saving it.
Split is a solid return to form for M. Night Shyamalan, but it's really James McAvoy's movie. It's worth seeing for McAvoy alone.
The Interview in a nutshell: Half-baked and ultimately forgettable.

You'll laugh at the bad dialogue, cringe as Calvin stalks the crew, and stare in utter disbelief as Doctor Pilot unironically recites Goodnight Moon when all hope seems lost. I cannot stress how stupid this scene is.
Zachariah is a complex and rewarding film, for those who don't mind the glacially slow pace.

Much of the action in UNCLE is rendered incoherent by Ritchie's chop-shop action direction. Ritchie has a distinctive style, but like Zack Snyder and Michael Bay he has a tendency to overplay his talents.
The Handmaiden is a GORGEOUS film, wonderfully acted by its three leads, with a twisty plot that will, at least once, elicit real shock.
The actual plot doesn't really matter-there's a computer doohickey, because when is there not?-what matters is Hart and Johnson bouncing off each other.
There's still several months of this year left, but Hell or High Water is a top-tenner for sure.
Nichols has yet to make a bad movie, and Midnight Special is not only within his usual style of excellence-despite that semi-wonky ending-it's also his most accessible film to date.
Individual scenes work well, but they amount to a disjointed whole, thanks to Nima Nourizadeh's direction.
In 2017, Chapter 2 is a triumphant return for cinema's coolest action anti-hero.
Me Before You is like a two-hour SNL skit parodying a bad romantic drama starring a baby-person and a sociopath.
The Founder should be a cautionary tale, a sad story about a pair of brothers done in by a ruthless businessman. Instead, despite a trio of very fine performances, it's oddly hollow.
The movie is basically Baby's Day Out except actually good and funny and featuring cartoon pets instead of a baby.
The Prophet is baffling and frustrating, and I can't recommend it because I do not know who this is meant to appeal to. Just read the book.
Suicide Squad shows all the signs of a movie subjected to heavy studio interference-terrible pacing, horrendous editing, uneven tone.

A Monster Calls is the cheapest therapy session you'll ever have. It's going to bring up a lot of stuff and make you feel very sad, and you will cry a bunch, but in the end you will experience catharsis.
Moonlight is a complicated film, though the elements are so gracefully interwoven it never feels burdensome to the viewer.
Deepwater Horizon is the most visceral and realistic disaster recreation since James Cameron sank a fake Titanic.
I love it, I can't guarantee you will all love it, too, but if you're open to trying a different flavor, The Lobster is definitely worth a shot.
Gold is a rather lazy, underachieving movie that exists solely for Matthew McConaughey to test how weird he can get before people stop watching.
The sense of fun remains strong throughout, even as the movie falls down a bit at the end. Everyone is obviously having a ball, and it's tremendous fun watching these four women together.
I recommend Mother's Day to no one, unless you happen to despise your mother and are looking for a passive-aggressive way to communicate your loathing to her.
Deadpool is breezy and fun and more jokes land than not, and it openly derides the usual moralizing of superhero movies, instead gleefully pursuing brains-splattering violence and profanity.
It's all ups and downs and I can't emphasize enough that the Beast is a horrifying pile of animated taxidermy.
I can't image the person who doesn't like Popstar. It's our twenty-first century Spinal Tap.

Trainwreck is an enjoyable movie; Trainwreck is a mixed bag. I wanted to love Trainwreck unconditionally and give it an A+ glowing review, like Spy, but in truth, while it is good enough and enjoyable enough, Trainwreck does have some problems.
Had Crimson Peak a script worthy of its production design, it could have been a twenty-first century Rebecca. Instead it's just another hollow candy-coated shell of a movie.
Hands down the best movie I've seen at TIFF, Spotlight is a phenomenal film, absolutely pitch perfect from start to finish.
War Dogs is a sweaty, bro-y, barely even sheepish celebration of Bush-era amorality dressed in coke and cash that squanders a brilliant scumbag performance from Jonah Hill.
Everybody Wants Some!! is a funny, light-hearted movie about the last days of summer. It's a nostalgic look back at a halcyon time.
The Next Cut is a comedy with dramatic heft or a drama with solid comedy, depending on how you look at it. Either way, it more than justifies returning to the barbershop.
The chemistry between the Avengers grounds it. At heart, it's a story about friends and friendship. A completely bananas story about friends and friendship, featuring a murderous robot.

Everyone will laugh at different things in Dear White People, and everyone will wince at different things. This is a great movie to see in a big group-you'll want to talk about it as soon as it's over.
The worldbuilding is as detailed and transporting as you expect from JK Rowling, who wrote the script, but you can tell she's a writer used to expansive novels where there's a lot more room to play.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For a movie that's about sexist double standards, it's the straight white dude who walks away with the most stolen scenes. Efron should only every make movies with Seth Rogen and director Nicholas Stoller.

Captain Fantastic wants to be a heart-warming look at an unusual family unit that extols the virtues of self-reliance, but instead it's a creepy case study of how a domineering father controls and limits his children.
They're flawed but likeable characters, set in an outlandish, ridiculously entertaining story. You've got to see The Nice Guys.
The music in Trolls is programmed by your local karaoke bar and sung like everyone's getting paid REALLY WELL.
For what it is-a procedural thriller-Wind River is above average.
Seriously, there's enough switcheroo hocus-pocus so slickly executed that it might be hard for James Bond to top it later this year.
The whole romantic subplot is really off putting.
It's a lazy, cheap, nonsensical ploy to separate you from your money.
... this is a case of all the good stuff being in the trailer.
Tyrannosaur is not for everyone. But if you can handle it, its rewards are worth the suffering.
So The A-Team was pretty much like Prince of Persia: not a great movie but entertaining. I laughed for two hours and everything blew up.
You could pretty much call it Aladdin Goes to War and get the point. Videogame movies are usually pretty thin on plot, but Prince of Persia is one game noted for its story.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Writer/director Drake Doremus... pulls very good performances from a young cast...
I expected Robin Hood to be Gladiator + Braveheart and I was pleased to find that it stands on its own as an entertaining movie.
In all, The Ides of March is watchable, but not a must-see.
Okay. Let's get this right at the beginning. I liked Moneyball... But hear me out. Moneyball could have been great.
Drive is the best love story I've seen at the movies in a long time.
It's a truly moving story that, despite a tendency toward the facile, never relies on tricks to make us feel something.
It's thought provoking-we should all be more circumspect with our hygiene-and it's a realistic look at what would happen if such a viral outbreak occurred...
I liked Iron Man 2. I laughed, I was engaged, I was entertained. I would see it again.
I can't recommend this movie highly enough.
Our Idiot Brother is an okay movie, a pretty good comedy, and a stellar vehicle for star Paul Rudd.
The acting makes this movie. Too often in a music movie the soundtrack takes first precedence, but here the acting is the center of the movie.
At no point did any of the symbolism in Sleeping Beauty feel organic.
Witty, macabre and funny, The Guard is a well-paced, well-acted movie that should not be missed if you're a fan of crime comedies.
It was funny. Like really funny, with genuine laughter, not those half-laugh, half-huff things that so many comedies settle for. In key moments, Easy A went for the gut-buster.

Scott Pilgrim is not what you expect. It's not what the marketing made you expect. It's better than that. Funnier, sweeter, with eye-popping visuals and characters who feel so flawed and real they could be your own brother, sister, or friend.
30 Minutes or Less wasn't terrible and when it did make me laugh, it made me laugh a lot. It was just built on the wrong comic premise.
At least Before We Go isn't a mess, but it's not much of anything else, either.
The Sorcerer's Apprentice wasn't bad so much as it was terribly dumb.

One of the best things about Nolan is that he writes his own material. He is in total control of the story. He isn't interpreting someone else's vision, he's translating his own thoughts to the screen.
All I expected from The Other Guys was that it makes me laugh, and it did, for two hours straight.
Knight & Day was not the triumphant return for which Cruise was hoping.
It's worth seeing for the acting alone-Davis and Spencer are outstanding-but we should be asking ourselves the difficult questions the movie tries so hard to avoid.
The story has big ideas but is underwritten, the acting is pedestrian at best, and though the CGI apes are very well actualized, they still look cartoony at times.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Overall, I enjoyed Crazy, Stupid, Love for what it was-a movie of moderate means and moderate ambitions that is made interesting by a strong ensemble cast...
As a debut feature film for Cornish, as the first break for its young star Boyega, as a throwback creature-feature and as a genre/comedy, Attack the Block just works.
It's the big hit Marvel needed to be and a strong platform for The Avengers...
Deathly Hallows part 2 struck all the right notes of action, adventure, friendship, courage and love.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is a hopelessly upsetting movie, you won't feel good about anything when it's over, but it's important to address these kinds of issues.
Horrible Bosses avoids the worst of the murder comedy pitfalls by making bad bosses the target of the plot.
The Duplass Brothers' streak lives on.
The final act kind of just falls apart and the big reveal about the time keeper's backstory fell flat.
Be prepared to embrace the year's most bizarre hero.
... it's still better than many movies, especially blockbuster types, but...It's just not one I feel compelled to make people see, like I did with The Dark Knight.
MacFarlane shows himself to be a capable live action director.
... the real stand out is Matthew McConaughey, who throws himself into the role of stripper-turned-MC Dallas.
It was the merger of that very real historical account and the fantastical vampire plot that made the book interesting, but the movie sacrificed a lot of that. Too much of that.
It can be nearly impossible to watch at times.

Director Ridley Scott is returning to his roots here, making the kind of atmospheric horror that builds up to its scare through judicious use of music, lighting and setting to set moods, and then punctuating scenes with explosive, frightening violence.
Overall, I enjoyed Huntsman thought it was a good first effort from [director Rupert] Sanders, though pacing and some lazy narrative devices dragged it down a bit.
It's a cold fish of a film.
The problems come largely from the script, which is bereft of character development and the humor is caught somewhere between too broad for camp and too weird for mainstream appeal.
It works on nearly every level and is a testament to a great director working with a great group of actors and a studio that knew when to get out of the way and let the creatives be creative.
Whatever you think it is, it's not that. It's better.
I'm not looking for revelatory performances from actors in bad action movies, but I do need to feel like they're participating and not phoning it in.
... PLEASE, believe me when I say that Mirror Mirror is not worth your time and certainly not your money.
This play very rarely gets performed in any medium, so for Shakespeare enthusiasts I'd say it's a must-see but you can skip it if that's not your bag.
It's too derivative to feel really special... but it approached some of the material boldly enough to at least feel like an interesting view of familiar ground.
John Carter isn't completely bad-a lot of individual elements work quite well-but it's a mess and it's so science fictiony as to be alienating.
Overall, The Grey is a solid movie that thinks a bit deeper than the usual action movie does and it features a strong performance from Neeson.
It's worth seeing, and hands-down it's one of your better options at the cineplex right now, but there's no urgency.
I found TinTin an unfulfilling experience at the movies.
Overall, Fincher's version is a chilly crime procedural, worth a watch but not world-burning in any way.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Extremely unsatisfying ending. And not better than The Black Stallion.
Everything, even the gender-bending, feels like a prop. For such a ripe story, Albert Nobbs is weirdly un-engaging and lacks any real urgency...
It-despite many instances beyond the suspension of disbelief-works.
... the movie overall doesn't quite live up to the sum of its best parts.
Theron deserves every ounce of notice she's getting for the performance.
All the good and great bits of Shame are down to Fassbender. Take him away and the movie doesn't actually have a lot going on.
From top to toe this is one of the best crafted, best acted, most tautly presented thrillers I've seen in a really long time.
... it's easily one of the best movies I've seen all year.
I wasn't expecting great storytelling because Tarsem isn't a great storyteller, but I did expect more from him visually.
... 21 Jump Street is consistently funny throughout, with a few really huge laughs peppered in the script.

Where I do not give Bay any kind of pass, the problem I identify as uniquely his own and the reason I think that, no matter how technically proficient he is, he is a bad filmmaker, is his utter tone deafness to stereotypes and characterizations.
If you haven't seen it, DON'T BOTHER.
It wasn't ground-breaking comedy but I enjoyed it.
Last Flag Flying finds a trio of middle-aged Vietnam veterans road-tripping through post-9/11 America on the saddest mission imaginable.
Sweet Virginia is a white-knuckle thriller that never lets up on the tension and dread.
The nicest thing to say about Justice League is that it won't give you a migraine.
Mudbound is a sprawling family drama and portrait of Americana that can-and should-stand next to classics like Giant.
If you want to know whether or not your kid is creepy, ask them what lesson they learned from Coco.
The Post is at once reassuring and warning, a reminder that we have survived democracy's test before, but also a prod to stay alert.
Kate Winslet can't save Wonder Wheel.
The Last Jedi is an epic to inspire, an adventure that truly carries you to a galaxy far, far away, and will hold in your heart as all the best stories do.
Phantom Thread is a delightful, sly treat, a cinematic bon bon of malcontented lust and power twisted into a perverted romance.
It's almost irrelevant that The Greatest Showman is not a very good movie because it's such an atrocious idea in the first place.
The Top Secret of a capella competition movies.
Bright is too boring to be the Best Worst Movie of 2017. It might just be the Worst Worst Movie of 2017.
All the Money in the World is above-average competent, and perfectly acceptable entertainment.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Insidious: The Last Key isn't even enjoyable in a bad horror movie kind of way, because it is at no point fun.
Jigsaw is not scary, it's just ugly and cruel.
The Commuter is executed with the gritty determination of people who really want to go home.
If at no point does it make your heart swell with positive emotion, then you're probably dead. Not just dead inside, you're probably an actual corpse.
As much as 12 Strong tries to focus on its specific moment, there is no escaping the looming shadow of this ongoing conflict.
Den of Thieves is an okay shoot-'em-up that is knee-capped by its overindulgent run time.
Cute and surprisingly funny, Peter Rabbit coasts on a great comedic turn from Domhnall Gleeson.
Destined for drunk-watching with your friends.
Thanks to Super Bowl hype, this is the world's flashiest bargain-bin rental.
We've waited for Black Panther for a long time, and it delivers on Every. Single. Level.
There is no good time for a movie like Death Wish.
Game Night is so absurd it's almost surreal, but...it works and never gets dragged down by its own concept.
Annihilation is sad, upsetting, scary, mystifying, and destined for debate.
Red Sparrow has a woman problem.
The Lodgers is low-key Gothic horror, less invested in jump scares than in its own moodiness.
A Wrinkle in Time is an imperfect movie with a big heart, and though it will have its detractors, it will also have its fans.
Gringo is a Coen Brothers movie for when you don't want to be bothered with the moral weight of an actual Coen Brothers movie.
Taraji P. Henson makes everything around her look better. She just can't quite save Proud Mary.
Equal parts absurd and surprisingly wonderful.
The Foreigner never sacrifices its own logic for a cheap thrill.
Geostorm is utterly ridiculous.
As a film, The Tree of Life is stellar on every level.
I'd highly recommend Cave of Forgotten Dreams-it's interesting, informative, and it demonstrates perfectly just what a waste of time and money 3D is for every lame summer action movie that comes out.
I really enjoyed Super 8. Kind of loved it, even.
Good actors make you care, even if the story doesn't.
It was WAY too long. It was WAY too bloated. It was WAY too self-indulgent. The plot was WAY too complicated.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The Snowman is an accidentally funny movie about graphic serial murder.
While ultimately forgettable, it's a pleasant enough diversion while it's happening.
Yes, this is a well-made, well-acted, entertaining movie. But it left me curiously empty afterward.
Your Highness is actually a pretty good looking film. It just isn't very funny.
The Trip will undoubtedly stand out as one of the best of the year.
... Source Code is a well-made sci-fi thriller, continuing the evolution of an interesting filmmaker in Duncan Jones.
... just plain bad.
The jokes, while solid, didn't feel focused enough. Paul is a nerd love letter when it could have been a monument.
... the laughs come more frequently and get progressively bigger.
... [Director Jordan Scott] has her father's knack for visuals to boot-she'll be a formidable director one day soon.
I didn't think it was possible to make SFX sequences more baffling and headache inducing than Transformers 2, but Battle: LA found a way.
There's no tension or angst in this movie... and the cheapsies SFX and bored, disinterested performances from the cast killed whatever moody emo vibe Hardwicke was trying to evoke.
It's a perfectly fine movie that could have been above-average good but was wrecked by too much story clutter and messy editing.
Even in a year flooded with excellent dramas, The Social Network is a standout.
If you want to see a horseracing movie with your family about the triumph of spirit through sport and the unique bond between a horse and its rider, just stay home and rent The Black Stallion.
Hereafter is another case of "poor material, decent direction".
Morning Glory can't find its footing between romantic comedy... and biting workplace comedy.
All around, Unstoppable was a pretty terrible movie.
It's the funniest movie you'll see this year, and easily one of the best.
Where the movie succeeds... it succeeds so well it's amazing.
The technical proficiency of Black Swan is eye-popping.
This movie isn't terrible. It's just forgettable.

Ken Hixon's (City by the Sea, Inventing the Abbotts) script is formulaic and doesn't take any chances... but [director Jake] Scott and his trio of actors elevate the material with light yet heartfelt touches.
Nothing about the movie felt fresh or inventive and it's hard to be interested when you're comparing it constantly to twelve different things that have come before.
Beastly isn't good but it's not nearly as awful as I expected.
In all, Behind Blue Skies is a serviceable coming-of-age tale, worth checking out if you're a Skarsgard fan. I'm sure Bill will be transitioning into English-language work shortly.
movie_title: Himlen är oskyldigt blå (Behind Blue Skies) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Not absolutely perfect, not exactly like the book, not enough, too much, give more, show me less-it's all of those things and still it's just RIGHT.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There isn't one wasted moment or word.
Whenever I did start to really enjoy Eclipse, the score killed it stone dead.
It's a rewarding film experience, if not an entirely satisfactory one.It's not for the faint of heart.
For a movie that wants to be about the hidden wounds of war, Billy Lynn is long walk into a cold and disaffected room.
... The Bad Batch isn't just a broken-down experiment, it's an actively offensive and gross exploitation flick...
... it's all about Dan Stevens. He is simply terrific as David.
Once in the woods the movie just rehashes the original, complete with panicked breathing, under-lit photography, snapping twigs, and so.
... the premise of Tracers is ludicrous.
Mostly I was just trying not to fall asleep.
... Brigsby Bear is a delightful oddity about one weird guy's belated coming of age and the chintzy TV show that helps him grow up.
There's enough payoff in the action to make Sicario feel satisfying, but underneath the combined polish of Villeneuve and Deakins is a hollow shell.

... for those willing to give it a shot it offers a rare experience, combining the kind of meticulous craftsmanship we expect from arthouse cinema with the hocking, terrifying violence we associate with exploitation films.
It's the craziest of the YA dystopia movies by far, taking the premise of "child murder as entertainment" to new, un-dreamed-of heights.
There is no momentum in Mockingjay Part 2, as the pacing is terrible.
The result is an uneven film that tests viewers' patience as holes in the narrative are filled with unhappy stares and beauty shots of the Maltese coastline...
Steve Jobs is not flawless, literally boxed in as it is by the setting, but the acting carries the film past its problems.
It's too bad-Cooties has promise as a premise but the end result is just a mess.
... Grandma is overall a funny, thoughtful, occasionally sad film about several generations of women in a family trying to deal with one another, anchored by Lily Tomlin's fantastic performance.
Straight Outta Compton ends up an above-average biopic, but it could have been so much more.
I've seen way worse movies aimed at men and boys, so I think everyone can chill out about a mediocre movie aimed at women.
This is not a movie about the things two lovers do to each other physically, it's about communication and intimacy and power, and how we wield those things for and against each other.
Blackhat, more than any Mann movie to date, represents a filmmaker alienated from his audience.
Big Ideas served in a movie that is ultimately unsatisfying.
This is a performance for the film history books, and one that Gyllenhaal inhabits totally.
The acting in Kill The Messenger can't be faulted. I just wish the movie itself was as focused and driven as Renner's performance.
The main issue with The Judge is that it's too long and schmaltzy, and the length makes the schmaltz worse because you have that much longer to be aware of it.
You made a vampire movie with no gore: Congratulations, you're Twilight.
I think it wants to be a scathing satire, but there's enough navel-gazing to take the edge off when the satire really needs to bite its hardest.
It's not that there's no value to Horns, it's just that what value there is, is severely handicapped by a dumb script.

Strong acting and detailed but unfussy direction by Joseph Kosinski carry the film through the few saccharine sticky spots, and overall the film is grounded in examining the kind of person who's drawn to this work, and what it costs them to do it.
... a methodical examination of 21st century spirituality and what it means to be evil or to forgive.
It's funny, light but thoughtful, and-surprisingly, for a sequel-fresh.
... I found it boring and unengaging, just a collection of "hey remember when" moments as opposed to actual introspection and exploration of what it means to grow up.

There may be little that's remarkable about the documentary's construction, but there's no escaping the infectious spirit of its subjects, the important work of their teacher, and their shared love of music.

There's little about this perceptive examination of the bonds of blood, the struggles of farming life, and the importance of finding hope and humour in even the bleakest of circumstances, that feels routine or overly familiar.
[A] faithful but fun movie [that should] still appeal to families ...
Feature debutant Eggers proves a master of mood more than story, though the success of the former overcomes the familiar nature of the latter.
It's a considerable and calculating task, and one that Son Of Saul handles commandingly.

Conflict seethes through Beyond the Mountains and Hills, infusing the feature with the unsettling air that can only come from knowing the truth of a tumultuous situation, but still wishing for change, acceptance and a reason to retain hope.
movie_title: Beyond the Mountains and Hills (Me'ever Laharim Vehagvaot) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's the sparkling individual components that comprise the ideal equation here, rather than any attempt to craft a new formula.
Eastwood scales back his style and rhetoric this time around, though not his earnestness.

The end result has momentum and meaning, and slides in amidst McQueen's excellent efforts; the only thing missing, particularly from a director known for his primal jolts and punishing journeys, is the visceral reaction.
Andini brings the twins' exploits to life with the requisite visual and tonal balance: crisp and naturalistic, yet also ethereal.
From walls that beat like a heart when they're touched, to a freewheeling third act that has to be seen to be believed, mother! is a movie driven by emotions and experiences.
Happy to go through the motions... much of its content is ripped from other, better efforts.
A probing, potent and propulsive celebration for the already acquainted and a lure for the uninitiated.
Mesmerising and provocative... with a simply stunning command of his visceral visuals and unnerving mood.
This intimate character study revels in Stanton's crumpled gaze, rugged skin and weary expression, as though they're the only things in the world worth looking at.
There's no one like Zvyagintsev at taking an already tense and heartbreaking situation into formally composed, emotionally brutal, absolutely astonishing territory.
A smart, spirited and soulful exploration of affection and intimacy - as driven by Binoche's enigmatic candour - that cuts deep.

movie_review_blurb: Love, life, creativity, connection, accepting others and acknowledging that nothing is permanent are all a part of this charming documentary.
Plenty of other animals have clucked, purred, barked, splashed and scurried their way through cute critter-focused documentaries, but not in this fashion.
Imaginative, enthralling, astute with its aesthetics and atmosphere, and insightful in contemplating both human and supernatural drama.
Directors Tali Shemesh and Asaf Sudry immerse viewers in a situation that's both horrifying and harrowing - and revealing about human nature in times of extreme crisis.
"[Macdonald's performance is] a star-making turn in a movie that's all about chasing star-making chances, and it comes with excellent support from Everett and Moriarty."
The kind of film that knows where its strengths reside, and how viewers are likely to react.
At its best when it embraces just what makes the toys fun.
Bright and shiny, the end result may be, but it's a by-the-numbers outing with less energy and momentum than its set piece-filled 141-minute running time needs.

As much as the actors do with the material, however, they can't quite lift the film beyond standard sappy romance territory.
Works best when it strides into the characters' inner darkness with confidence and commitment, rather than when it's laying down clues about its ultimate end game.
If you're on the film's wavelength, plenty of its beats and rhythms will strike a chord.
Flat and bland in style, plot and emotion, it's a work completely devoid of interest and scares.
Obvious in its narrative path but delicate and compassionate in its treatment of the expected, a measured and moving film results.

Proves intense, involving and utterly uncompromising in its view of human nature, its commentary on modern Kazakhstan and its astonishing central performance from non-professional first-timer Laura Koroleva.
In a film that doesn't shy away from depicting harsh truths, Zhou lets the drama unravel without any overt histrionics; never playing the situation for easy tears or cathartic laughs.

King and Riggs' famous tussle inspires an engaging, entertaining effort - one that's as much about the showdown at its centre as it is the struggles it stood for.
This polished noir benefits greatly from splashing its various elements around in just the right manner.

Takes to its satirical task with glee - think slick, montage-heavy visuals, an upbeat vibe and soundtrack, and absolutely no misapprehensions about the sort of entertaining, tongue-in-cheek movie that it wants to be.
An eye-opening film... and one that also acts as a work of advocacy for a different relationship between fast fashion consumption and its production.
A sober look at an area more typically relegated to horror movies.
Much, much more than just the human equivalent of a ghost emoji standing in an Instagram snap... one of the most astute depictions of grief to reach cinemas in a long time.

Bleak in its kidnapping contents but bright in its images.

movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

Psychologically complex, emotionally compelling ...

Smart, funny and perceptive... brimming with well-observed scenarios, characters and emotions.

Measured but involving... an engaging slice-of-life effort.
An acerbic, entertaining, surreal and statement-making portrait.

Brought to life in the furrowed brows and yearning gazes of the movie's soulful lead performances.
