Everything about the society surrounding contemporary art galleries comes under the microscope in what proves a dense and disarming effort.
It's easy to feel as though Haneke is retracing his own footsteps, and he is, but he's doing so with purpose and self-awareness.
The details are revelatory, but, aping Lynch's own directorial style, so is the mood.
A good time is all but guaranteed as you watch Benny and Josh Safdie's grubby, energetic heist movie unfold.
Demands that kind of close attention, and rewards it as well.
Revels in sticking with a template-like tale, purely to afford the director a platform to thrust his specific brand of flair to the fore.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Smack[s] of talent, and of toiling valiantly to do justice to conceptually intriguing yet not completely convincing material.
After spending his career watching, curating and analysing movies, Australia's beloved film critic makes an easy, informative and engaging switch to starring in his own.
Turns sticking with what works into an action opera that knows when to dazzle with a symphony of shoot-outs, but also knows when enjoying Keanu's menacing presence is enough.

Ensuring that chaos envelops quietly, cracks deepen slowly and fortitude gradually triumphs over fragility is just one of Zegers' many feats in a film that doesn't ask audiences to warm to its complicated central character, but to understand her.
Promised Land deftly flits from biography to impact study to cinematic essay on the boom and bust of happiness-peddling myths, drawing a clear line from the music king to the current US leader.
Gabriel and the Mountain offers a moving look at the transformative nature of travel, both on those hopping around the world in search of a new perspective and those they encounter along the way.
movie_title: Gabriel and the Mountain (Gabriel e a montanha) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Jumping between bureaucratic manoeuvring and matters of the heart isn't always packaged with the smoothest transitions, and doesn't give either side of the story much depth.
It's hardly surprising that Hawn's rapport with Schumer is far and away the best thing about this routine jaunt through the jungle.
Don't Tell's fates are as firmly entwined with its leading lady as they are with the real-life story at its core.
Directors Joachim Rønning and Espen Sandberg soon lose control of their vessel, serving up bland nautical action alongside their predictably unbearable protagonist.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Wilson, the man, may serve up great work from Harrelson, but Wilson, the movie, soon proves that 94 minutes in the character's company are far too many.
[A] pained, inane take on crime-fighting lifeguards.
Makala takes the observational approach to the hardships of Congolese life, charting a tough but insightful journey.
A highly unsettling debut that heralds the emergence of a promising new Aussie filmmaking talent.
Such an awful chapter of history doesn't need to be packaged as a grand romance to evoke an emotional reaction.
A loving attempt to tackle a familiar genre, the film does everything it can to speed into new territory. Alas, it gets lost along the way.
It wears its affection on its sleeves - or, perhaps its collar - but pairs that obvious love with thoughtful insights.
A superhero origin story infused with the spirit of feminist adventure, and told with smarts, heart, and a different point-of-view.

There's little that's subtle about that combination of elements, nor about director Kriv Stenders and writer Stephen M. Irwin's exploration of the attitudes that both bind and divide contemporary Australia.
Sensible, envious, posh, feisty, kooky Aussie: the women here have about as much dimension as members of a '90s girl band.
The movie's real point of interest is right there in its name: an enigmatic woman, the talented actress that brings her to life, and the mystery that follows.
With class inequalities, academic pressures and institutionalised corruption among its multiple-choice roster of deeper insights, this slick, shrewd film more than earns a passing grade.
For all of its stylistic assurance, casting might be Una's strongest asset.
Filled with fantastic actresses not only interacting with cultural touchstones, but playing characters trying to make sense of their life through art.
It's not the details already splashed across the tabloids with frequency that prove informative, but glimpsing the pain lingering behind the headlines.
Bogged down by blatant stereotypes, wan banter, obvious observations about the intersection of class systems, and rote wisdom about having the strength to be yourself and forge your own path.

Offers an astute perspective on the immigrant experience, multicultural communities, and trying to reconcile traditional and modern cultures - all while telling a tale of love and life that's authentic, affectionate and amusing.
Ellipsis' banter, almost-romantic friendship, and assemblage of offbeat altercations keep to a well-worn path, even if the film is staged and shot with energy and affection.
Cox's towering performance makes Churchill feel as though it's stepping into fresh territory.
You may have seen Terminator 2 a million times, but this is one true classic that never gets old.
If you're after light entertainment, heavy spectacle and a tinge of crazy cinematic magic, Valerian will deliver.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: So who is Al Gore's follow-up to the Oscar-winning An Inconvenient Truth for? As it turns out, very compellingly: you and me.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Yet, despite ostensibly doing everything "right", for most of its run-time the film doesn't quite manage to deliver the thrills.
This documentary is simple to its core in its premise and construction, yet hugely affecting.

Villeneuve has taken the double-edged sword of the update and created a Blade Runner 2049 worthy of honouring its ancestor, while bringing it appropriately into the mid-21st Century.

With top-notch sound design, music well-chosen for a teen audience and, most importantly, really sharp acting from all involved, The Changeover is a worthy addition to the cinematic YA genre which can proudly boast a local edge.
... even though the characters are in the most perilous of circumstances, the viewer manages not to feel a thing.

Incomplete and unpublished by the time of his death eight years later, the letters have been picked up by Haitian filmmaker Raoul Peck who brings Baldwin's typically insightful and beautifully articulated words to life...

Unfortunately, Atomic Blonde turns out to be nothing more than a series of sometimes visually impressive, but perpetually banal sequences in a story that lacks interest or coherence, played out by characters who have no substance.
Pitch Perfect 3 is not exactly the epitome of 21st century, post-Weinstein, feminist cinema.

Spall and Meaney are fantastic, Spall's seemingly overblown portrayal of the blustering Bible-basher Paisley more on-point than you would care to believe, with Meaney selling McGuinness as a thoroughly nice chap.

Daphne du Maurier may not seem like the most relevant author to be plundering for a 21st Century film script, but this accomplished cinematic rendering proves her moody, slightly confusing, dark and desperately romantic tales still have their place.

A bit like The Hangover peopled by the fairer sex, Rough Night boasts five terrific performances from its leading ladies and produces a comedy of errors which delivers more laughs-out-loud than I've had in months.

Much of Zootopia's charm results from its wonderful animation and captivating energy, but at heart it's the witty, insightful script around deeper socio-political issues which makes it truly satisfying for any grown-up who goes to see it.

Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are shaping up to be today's equivalent of Garland and Rooney, this third outing (after Crazy, Stupid, Love and Gangster Squad) demonstrating yet again their chemistry and endearing camaraderie.
While there are numerous nods to cultural references only a local audience will appreciate, Ricky and Hec's emotional journey is one which every viewer can climb aboard.
Nicely shot, smartly acted and efficient in its telling.
Not altogether pleasant, but undeniably gripping.
If your heart isn't pounding for most of the film, you're not alive.
... the overall impact of Waru is stunning and it is impossible not to be moved and impressed in equal measure.
With four hearty laughs in the first two minutes, David Brent: Life on the Road starts with promise and goes on to be an immensely satisfying, sometimes uncomfortable, return to form.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Sadly, the promising start soon falls flat, and we're left with an unmemorable attempt to replace Tobey Maguire and Andrew Garfield, both of whose tales about the boy-superhero far surpass this one.
It tells the poignant true story of Canadian folk artist Maud Lewis, whose famously naïve, but charming paintings garnered the humble native of Nova Scotia world-wide celebrity.
... while there are several beautiful, aquatic set-pieces, the story shuffles predictably towards its conflict and conclusion. For those who want look and feel, this may be enough.
Far from being the biopic of a city, Detroit is at any rate a dark chapter in its history.
The only thing more interesting than watching how someone turns into a superhero is seeing them lose that power.
... for all its unlikely and fantastical nature, Film Stars is a lovely love story.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [Director Sally] Potter has hit a more crowd-friendly jackpot with The Party, not just because of her top-drawer cast, but writing witty, fast-paced dialogue to be spat out by unlikeable and yet intoxicating characters...

The film makes little pretence of being high-brow or particularly cinematic in its crafting (though its editing matches the speedy dialogue), but as a pacey tell-all it's a fascinating and entertaining watch.

But the movie which starts with incredible promise and is utterly engrossing then morphs inexplicably into a completely different film halfway through. And so here we are, disappointed and bewildered, reading a three-star review.
Thanks to sharp writing, the talents of Robbie and Janney, and, at heart, compassion for its subject, I, Tonya is frequently hilarious, crucially revealing and resoundingly enjoyable.
... thankfully Only the Brave eschews sentiment and manipulation to deliver a well-acted, informative and ultimately heartfelt movie.
... it doesn't take itself too seriously, and for the most part it's just a jolly entertaining romp of a revenge flick.
... Call Me By Your Name can only be described as a perfect film.
... Breathe turns out to be quite charming and frequently delightful.
Thankfully The Last Jedi won't be the last Jedi movie, but it should be your next.
... a fascinating exposé of the behind-the-scenes psychology that drove these world-class players and gave them the reputations they've carried for life.

... Daddy's Home 2 is for the most part thuddingly unfunny and ultimately obnoxious.
This is Christchurch filmmaker Nic Gorman's feature debut as writer-director - and what intelligent writing and directing it is.
... Justice League is enjoyable, smart and interesting, with touches of humour, an almost overwhelmingly high-calibre cast, and plenty going on.
... one of the most brilliantly original and exhilarating films of the year.

Extremely graphic, violent Vietnam War film.

Dreadful. Absolutely inappropriate for kids.

Along the lines of Spielberg's Schindler's List -- at once moving and painful to watch.

As is usual with any Mike Leigh film -- a style unique and trademarked by now -- his ensemble is a collection of remarkably adept actors who know their characters so well they could stay in character for weeks, continually improvising, as they often do.
It's a high wire act that might leave some feeling left behind. Somehow, though, Boyle pulls it off not by backing off the speechifying but by leaning into it and allowing it to sing.
Every shot is a thing of beauty. For most of this film I had the impulse to hoist my camera and take a snapshot of it. It is just one dizzying image after another.
In an era where there are very few truly surprising films, Borgman is one of the rare movies that manages to find something entirely new to say, with original, oddly drawn characters.
The supporting cast, including Helena Bonham Carter, Romola Garai and Anne-Marie Duff, are all top notch, and a reminder of how few films like this exist anywhere.
This is a breathtaking film for those who still believe in the power of imagination, who haven't given all of it over to artists who do the work for you.

movie_review_blurb: It feels alive and fresh -- the kind of cinema that doesn't waste a second.
This latest incarnation of the great American Western finds its truth in the tangled roots of our own mythmaking.
There isn't a single scene that falls flat or feels false.
The Dardennes brothers' latest tale from the grim streets of the industrial suburb of Liège in Belgium is another quietly powerful masterpiece; it's perhaps their best film since The Child.
What was charmingly loose-limbed in Jarmusch's earlier films now seems mannered and tired.
If Arrival's ending is a little too upbeat and the explanations for the fractured narrative leave one a bit puzzled, it's still a worthy attempt to refresh a familiar story.
Doctor Strange could descend into a clutch of clichés, but director/writer Scott Derrickson has injected plenty of wit. The visuals, especially in the modern-world sequences, are stunning.

movie_review_blurb: Its elliptical narrative will certainly stay with you, but it's not a joyous experience.

To those who occasionally like their movies to be tender-hearted, Sweet Bean is a miniature treat.
Gripes aside, this is a far better follow up to the original than 1989's cynically lacklustre Ghostbusters 2, and the result is genuinely warm-hearted summer fun.

If there were a way to switch off the dialogue, leaving the images, music and layered soundscape, Knight of Cups would be wondrous. As it is, it's a bit of an endurance test.
This is not comfortable viewing, but the film is the better for it.
It's a risky venture, remaking a much-loved Disney classic, but Jon Favreau has tackled The Jungle Book with considerable enthusiasm.

This is a fresh narrative in an era where films aimed at young audiences are dominated by sequels, prequels, remakes, comic book and TV adaptations, and it is all the better for it.

A must-see for fans of the original, but a shorter running time and less energetic CGI excess might have done this flawed horror fantasy a serious favour.
As a pure thriller, it's entertaining - but The Kingdom tries too hard to be a crowd-pleaser, and ends up standing in the shadows of better and more provocative movies.
This hugely entertaining horror fable for all the family might suffer from pacing problems, but it's also a true original that still stands out from today's CGI-heavy crowd.
Veering from witty to occasionally trite, Wristcutters: A Love Story has plenty of originality on its side, but never manages to be more than the sum of its self-consciously quirky parts.
It's not for the easily offended, but look past the fabulously crude dialogue, and Superbad is one of the most consistently funny and enjoyable teen comedies in years.
A hypnotic disaster that's truly fascinating - if only for all the wrong reasons.
It's not quite as enchanted or magical as it could have been, but this family romp still manages to be good fun, and is lifted by fantastic turns from Amy Adams and James Marsden.
A gloriously insane journey into the weirder reaches of rock, Air Guitar Nation is a funny, funky and oddly moving burst of lively factual entertainment.
An effective and meticulous character drama, Breach doesn't quite make the most of its story but still tells a fascinating tale, aided by Chris Cooper's magnetic central performance.
An engaging mix of sports movie and psychological drama that rises above the routine enough times to excuse some of its more predictable moments.
Don't let the over-familiar nature of the plot fool you. This Asian horror thriller rises above its flaws to deliver a tightly constructed, affecting, and downright terrifying ride.
A horribly mannered, self-conscious film that gets more tiresome as it goes along.
An engaging portrait of childhood, this well-meaning family film rises above its flaws, and delivers a surprisingly hefty emotional punch.
Large chunks have been lost in translation.
The result is a delirious, turbo-charged roar of a movie that plays like Spartacus on bizarre drugs.
Has plenty of atmosphere but can't make up for unpleasant characters and a meandering story.
Carrey is effectively sinister, the visuals are often amazing, but there's less to this murky psycho-thriller than meets the eye.
Bizarre, involving and highly original, this leftfield gangland fable adds up to a strange, surprisingly moving experience.
A film which builds into a gripping blend of When We Were Kings and 2001: A Space Odyssey.
movie_title: Game Over: Kasparov and the Machine (2004)

movie_review_blurb: License To Wed never escapes the combined trap of terminal blandness and a severe lack of decent jokes.

If the idea of three squeaky-voiced squirrels as pop gods makes you shudder, Alvin And The Chipmunks won't make you change your mind - but there's enough spritely mischief in this flawed family comedy to provide some light-hearted fun.
It's an interesting approach to bridging two very different disciplines -- it's just a pity they didn't find a better script to try it out on.
A raucous mix of black comedy and noir thriller.
Kids too young for Lord Of The Rings may be distracted by this below average fantasy, but for everyone else this is derivative and silly.
It's not quite a disaster but this disappointing and poorly executed fantasy adventure never reaches the level of magic and enchantment it needs to succeed.

Wild, crazy and packed with memorable moments, this South Korean homage to the western may not be thought-provoking or particularly deep, but it's also one of the most genuinely fun and inventive movies to hit the screen in quite some time.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It may be a definite upswing in quality for the series, but if you thought the previous two films were overblown goth-horror nonsense, Rise Of The Lycans really isn't going to change your mind...
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Making up for a selection of recent Asian Horror disappointments, this lush, surreal and brilliantly dark fairy tale is an entertaining and deliciously unsettling experience.
Veering between intelligent and unpleasant, this apocalyptic drama isn't without its strong moments, but is ultimately too grim and pretentious for its own good.
A must-watch for lovers of the strange and unusual, this visually ravishing oddball drama has sequences of genuine beauty and charm - even if it won't be to everyone's taste.
A promising idea is let down by weak storytelling in this well-played but lacklustre Brit crime thriller.
Despite an impressive cast and a well-known director, this misfiring costume drama is a haphazard mess that ends up more unintentionally funny than emotionally engaging.
Showcasing a welcome lack of big-budget attitude, The Kite Runner makes up for its small flaws with an engaging, thought-provoking story and a willingness to tackle some very dark issues.
Adult and provocative, Elegy doesn't entirely pull off its complex philosophical juggling act, but it's an interesting and atmospheric piece of cinema, aided by some truly excellent performances.
Another in the long line of Pixar classics -- beautiful, energetic, intelligent, satirical, crammed full of gorgeous design, and genuinely heartwarming.
Sadly, the fact that it's attached to a successful toyline means it barely matters whether it's good or not.
It won't convert the unfaithful but this messy, energetic action adventure is lurid fun, and may well re-ignite the popularity of the heroes in a half-shell.
While this idea may have been enough to happily fill 25 minutes, the film version fails to effectively stretch it out to feature-length.
stodgy and listless futuristic thriller that only ever echoes other cinematic sci-fi tomorrows.
A production that's both amazing to look at and hard to enjoy, The Banquet contains plenty of visual pleasures, but ties its gloomy story in too many knots to be truly entertaining.
movie_title: Ye yan (Legend of the Black Scorpion) (The Banquet) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's not quite a disaster but this disappointing Apatow-produced teen comedy still gets a 'Could Do Much Better' on its report card.
An odd tale of life on the winding streets of Paris, The Flight Of The Red Balloon isn't without its moments of beauty, but its vague story and aimless tone is more likely to frustrate than enchant.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A universe away from everyday American teen movies, this engaging and empathetic portrait of teenage life is packed full of stylish moments.
With superb acting and great dialogue, this acerbic comic drama has some excellent moments, but it too often feels like being on an enforced holiday with people you'd rather not spend any time with.
Every action sequence is imaginatively mounted, from a dizzying fight on a high tower, to the sight of Li taking on a wrestler twice his size...
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Superb performances from the fittingly eclectic array of actors. Ballard would be proud.

Disney's beloved story about Mowgli-the-man-cub, raised by wolves, befriended by a bear and threatened by a terrifying tiger, has been given a CGI-drenched makeover that will warm the heart of even the most cynical critic.
